front.title: Mapping from LWM2M model to CoMI YANG model

abstract.t: This document defines a set of rules to convert a LWM2M xml-based device specification to a YANG MODULE. The invocation of the server executing the converted YANG code makes use of CoMI. The mapping from the original LWM2M uri to the corresponding CoMI URI is presented.

note.title: Note
note.t: Discussion and suggestions for improvement are requested, and should be sent to roll@ietf.org.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Standardization organizations define interfaces hosted by processors to manipulate the connected equipment. Examples of such standardization organizations are BACnet, KNX, ZigBee, oBIX, OMA/IPSO, and many others. These organizations plan to move to resource based interfaces. The data models proposed by these organizations are hierarchical models that can be specified in XML and describe classes with attributes and operations that can be instantiated to objects. An example is the OMA LWM2M (see ) Object model, that standardizes eight numbered object types for device management. IPSO (see ) expands those objects to handle applications. This document describes rules to translate xml specifications of the LWM2M/IPSO organizations to YANG .

section.title: Conversion rules LWM2M to YANG
section.t: LWM2M objects are typed, where each type is identified with a number. The object provides one or more instances which are numbered. An instance is composed of resources, also identified with numbers. An instance on a host can be accessed with the example URI: http://example.com/object/instance/resource, where resource, instance and object are numbers, specified by the LWM2M specification.
When using YANG, the object identifiers, followed by the resource identifier, are YANG strings instead of numbers.

For an automatic translation from the XML LWM2M specification to a YANG specification, the following rules apply for access, optional, units, and range specifications:
The optional/mandatory aspect of the LWM2M resource is covered by the leaf's mandatory "false/true" statement of YANG.
The R,W access aspects of a data item are translated using config statement. Config "false" means R access, config "true" means RW access.
When the YANG RPC is specified the E access is meant. In RPCs are modelled for NETCONF using YANG input and output parameters. When input parameters are added, ER access is meant; when output parameters are added, WR access is meant and with both input and output parameters ERW access is meant.
To specify the range of a data resource the YANG range statement is used.
The YANG units statement is used to express the units.
In the YANG specification the LWM2M resources are specified as leafs of a YANG list. The YANG list is preceded by leaf called instance_number which contains the LWM2M instance identifier. The instance_number is declared key in the YANG list.

By modelling OMA objects as YANG lists, the numbered OMA object instances can be provided by assigning to each list object an "instance" key attribute. The numbering of the instance does not need to be consecutive. The OMA resources are the other leafs of the list object. Consequently, the list element can be referenced by its instance number, as is the case for OMA instances.

The YANG identifiers are strings and need to be mapped to numbered identifiers. The appendices show 4 ways to represent the LWM2M device ID and resource ID in the YANG specification.
In , illegal YANG identifiers are represented as integers. This approach cannot be compiled by YANG compilers. In , Yang Identifiers are modelled as strings that start with string "ID" followed by the identifier number (see module humidityID). In , Yang Identifiers of types and resources are modelled as strings that represent the type- and resource- name (see module humidityNM). In , the device object is modelled as a container composed of an identifier and a list of instances. The list instance is composed of an instance number and a set of resource containers. The resource container is composed of the pair (attribute identifier number, IPSO resource specification)(see module humidityLF).
Below the tree diagrams (see for an explanation) of the three valid YANG modules are shown.

section.title: URI convention
section.t: The invocation URI of a LWM2M resource looks like:
http://example.com/type/instance/resource
In this section it is assumed that the YANG mapping of is used.
When YANG is used, the LWM2M resource invocation can follow the RESTCONF convention using http, or the CoMI convention using CoAP.
When using RESTCONF the invocation will look like:
http://example.com/type/instance=0/resource

In the case of CoMI the type/resource name is converted to a numeric identifier to reduce the payload size. The instance is specified in a query parameter. Consequently, the LWM2M resource on a host containing a YANG specification is accessed with:
coap:// example.com/type/resource?keys=0
Assuming that IPSO-humidity/Sensor_Value converts to 5700, the URI for the CoMI invocation of instance 0 of IPSO-humidity/Sensor_value will look like:
coap://example.com/5700?keys=0
For LWM2M types with only one instance, the keys=0 can be omitted.

section.title: YANG identifiers as numbers
section.t: Yang Identifiers are modelled as simple integers. This is not allowed in YANG. The device object is modelled as a list that contains multiple instances.

section.title: YANG identifiers as IDnumbers
section.t: Yang Identifiers are modelled as string that starts with ID followed by the identifier number. The device object is modelled as a list that contains multiple instances.

section.title: YANG identifiers as additional leaf
section.t: The device object is modelled as a container composed of an identifier and a list of instances. The list instance is composed of an instance number and a set of resource containers. The resource container is composed of the pair (attribute identifier number, IPSO resource specification).
